what: Change to that virtual environment and install acro
title: Installation Guides
text: Anaconda comes GUI makes process easy. system using conda command line : Windowsfrom command line python’s pip package manager: followed linux/mac using conda:
code: conda activate r-acro conda install conda-forge::acro  #assuming this completes successfully you can now exit conda deactivate r-acro # In cmd.exe r-acro\Scripts\activate.bat # In PowerShell r-acro\Scripts\Activate.ps1 python -m pip install acro #assuming this completes successfully you can now exit the virtual environment deactivate source r-acro/bin/activate #you should see the your command prompt change to show (r-acro) python -m pip install acro #assuming this completes successfully you can now exit the virtual environment deactivate

what: Check if acro is installed and if it is not install it from CRAN
title: acro R Notebook
code: # Check if acro is installed if (!requireNamespace("acro", quietly = TRUE)) {   # If not installed, install it   install.packages("acro") }

title: acro R Notebook
text: First , need call acro_init() initialise acro object. function takes parameter suppress can TRUE FALSE choose whether automatically apply suppression results . default suppression.

title: acro R Notebook
text: dataset used example notebook nursery dataset OpenML. code reads data folder called “nursery_data” assume level folder working. path might need changed data downloaded stored elsewhere. Convert children column integers, replacing ‘’ random int range 4-10
code: data <- farff::readARFF("data/nursery.arff") data <- as.data.frame(data)  names(data)[names(data) == "class"] <- "recommend" data$children <- as.numeric(as.character(data$children)) data[is.na(data)] <- round(runif(sum(is.na(data)), min = 4, max = 10), 0) unique(data$children)

previous_headings: Examples of producing tabular output using acro
title: acro R Notebook
code: index <- data[, c("recommend")] columns <- data[, c("parents")] values <- data[, c("children")]  # convert the values to an array values <- matrix(values, ncol = 1)  table <- acro_crosstab(index = index, columns = columns, values = values, aggfunc = "sum") table

previous_headings: Examples of producing tabular output using acro
title: acro R Notebook
code: index <- data[, c("parents")] columns <- data[, c("social")]  table <- acro_table(index = index, columns = columns, deparse.level = 1) table

previous_headings: Examples of producing tabular output using acro
title: acro R Notebook
code: index <- "parents" values <- "children" aggfunc <- list("mean", "std")  table <- acro_pivot_table(data, values = values, index = index, aggfunc = aggfunc) table

previous_headings: Examples of producing regression outputs using acro
what: Start by manipulating the nursery data to get two numeric variables
title: acro R Notebook
text: ‘recommend’ column converted integer scale
code: data$recommend <- as.character(data$recommend) data$recommend[which(data$recommend == "not_recom")] <- "0" data$recommend[which(data$recommend == "recommend")] <- "1" data$recommend[which(data$recommend == "very_recom")] <- "2" data$recommend[which(data$recommend == "priority")] <- "3" data$recommend[which(data$recommend == "spec_prior")] <- "4" data$recommend <- as.numeric(data$recommend) # extract relevant columns df <- data[, c("recommend", "children")] # drop rows with missing values df <- df[complete.cases(df), ] # formula to fit formula <- "recommend ~ children"

previous_headings: Examples of producing regression outputs using acro
title: acro R Notebook

previous_headings: Examples of producing regression outputs using acro
title: acro R Notebook
text: example logit regression using ACRO use different combination variables original dataset.
code: # extract relevant columns df <- data[, c("finance", "children")] # drop rows with missing values df <- df[complete.cases(df), ] # convert finance to numeric df <- transform(df, finance = as.numeric(finance)) # subtract 1 to make 1s and 2S into 0a and 1s df$finance <- df$finance - 1 # formula to fit formula <- "finance ~ children" acro_glm(formula = formula, data = df, family = "logit")

title: A Tool for Semi-Automating the Statistical Disclosure Control of Research Outputs
text: ACRO free open source tool supports semi-automated checking research outputs (SACRO) privacy disclosure within secure data environments. SACRO framework applies best-practice principles-based statistical disclosure control (SDC) techniques --fly researchers conduct analysis. SACRO designed assist human checkers rather seeking replace current automated rules-based approaches.

title: A Tool for Semi-Automating the Statistical Disclosure Control of Research Outputs
text: ACRO implements principles-based statistical disclosure control (SDC) methodology : Automatically identifies potentially disclosive outputs Applies optional disclosure mitigation strategies Reports reasons applying SDC Produces summary documents output checkers

previous_headings: Core Features
title: A Tool for Semi-Automating the Statistical Disclosure Control of Research Outputs
text: Drop-replacements common Python analysis commands (pandas, statsmodels, etc.) configurable disclosure checks Automated sensitivity tests : frequency thresholds, dominance (p%, NK rules, etc.), residual degrees--freedom checks Optional mitigations : suppression, rounding, come Session management : track, rename, comment, remove, add exceptions, finalise reports Configurable risk parameters via YAML files Generates auditable reports JSON Excel

previous_headings: Core Features
title: A Tool for Semi-Automating the Statistical Disclosure Control of Research Outputs
text: Free open source MIT (ACRO) / GPLv3 (SACRO Viewer) Easy install via PyPI, CRAN, GitHub; cross-platform (Linux, macOS, Windows) Familiar APIs - function signatures native commands: acro.crosstab mirrors pandas.crosstab, etc. Comprehensive coverage - tables, regressions, histograms, survival plots, etc. Transparent & auditable - clear reports, stored queries, designed human-checkers Configurable & extensible - organisation-defined disclosure rules, multi-language support Scalable - lightweight, session-based, local execution

title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: page provides comprehensive overview ACRO’s capabilities researchers, developers, non-technical stakeholders. ACRO supports wide range statistical analysis functions automated disclosure control.

previous_headings: Supported Data Analysis Functions
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: Researchers: Create frequency tables cross-tabulations automatic cell suppression small counts. ACRO Supports: crosstab() - Cross-tabulation two variables frequency counting pivot_table() - Spreadsheet-style pivot tables aggregation functions table() - Simple frequency tables categorical data (R interface ) Technical Details: - ACRO suppresses, reports reason , value aggregation statistic (mean, median, variance, etc.) cell deemed sensitive - current version ACRO supports three common tests sensitivity: ensuring number contributors frequency threshold, testing dominance via N-K rules - N-K Rule : dominance test top N contributors account K% total, cell considered disclosive - Frequency Threshold : Cells fewer specified number contributors suppressed - thresholds configurable via YAML configuration files - detailed methodology, see research paper - Automatic flagging negative missing values human review Example Use Cases: - Survey response analysis demographics - Clinical trial outcome tables - Market research cross-tabulations - Educational assessment reporting

previous_headings: Supported Data Analysis Functions
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: Researchers: Run regression analyses automated checks model outputs residual degrees freedom. ACRO Supports: ols() - Ordinary Least Squares linear regression logit() - Logistic regression binary outcomes probit() - Probit regression binary outcomes Technical Details: - regressions linear, probit, logit, tests verify number residual degrees freedom exceeds threshold - Within ACRO Python package, functionality ‘ACRO’ class split number separate classes maintainability extensibility. ‘Tables’ class contains code necessary perform disclosure checks tabular data, crosstab. separate ‘Regression’ class contains code checking regressions logit probit Example Use Cases: - Economic modeling policy analysis - Medical research clinical studies - Social science research - Business analytics forecasting

previous_headings: Programming Language Support
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: Developers: ACRO package lightweight Python tool sits well-known analysis tools produce outputs tables, plots, statistical models Supported Libraries: - Pandas - data manipulation table creation - Statsmodels - statistical modeling regression analysis - NumPy - numerical computations Python Version Support: - Python 3.10, 3.11, 3.12, 3.13

previous_headings: Programming Language Support
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: R Users: Additional programming languages R package supported providing front-end packages interface core ACRO Python back-end Integration Features: - Native R syntax workflows - R Markdown Shiny application support - Tidyverse compatibility - CRAN package availability Getting Started R: r library(“acro”) acro_init(suppress = TRUE)

previous_headings: Programming Language Support
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: Stata Users: ACRO designed let use familiar commands R, Stata Python Features: - Drop-replacement standard Stata commands - Familiar Stata syntax workflows - Integration existing Stata scripts

previous_headings: Disclosure Control Features
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: ACRO Checks: Tables: - Minimum cell counts (frequency thresholds) - Dominance rules (N-K rules concentration) - Presence negative missing values Statistical Models: - Residual degrees freedom thresholds - Model fit diagnostics - Parameter significance testing Non-Technical Users: ACRO automatically identifies research outputs might reveal sensitive information individuals organizations, applying industry-standard privacy protection rules without requiring manual review every result.

previous_headings: Disclosure Control Features
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: ACRO Provides: Suppression Masks - Clear indication results hidden Summary Reports - Detailed explanation disclosure checks performed Audit Trails - Complete record analysis steps decisions Exception Handling - Process requesting release flagged outputs Workflow Integration: finalise function : Check output “fail” “review” status exception, asked enter one. Write outputs directory. directory contains everything output checkers need make decision

previous_headings: Supported Environments
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: ACRO Works: - Trusted Research Environments (TREs) - Data safe havens - Secure data centers - Academic research computing facilities - Government statistical offices - Healthcare research environments Installation: See Installation complete installation instructions system requirements.

previous_headings: Integration Capabilities
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: Research Teams: ACRO integrates seamlessly existing data analysis workflows, requiring minimal changes current practices adding comprehensive privacy protection. Supported Workflows: - Jupyter notebook analysis - R Markdown documents - Stata -files scripts - Batch processing automation - Interactive analysis sessions Data Sources: - CSV Excel files - Database connections - Survey data platforms - Administrative datasets - Clinical trial databases

previous_headings: Integration Capabilities
title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: ACRO Produces: - Standard CSV files tables - JSON metadata files automation - Excel workbooks human reviewers - PDF reports output checkers - HTML summaries researchers Review Process Support: Compatible SACRO-Viewer interactive output review data controllers compliance officers.

title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: System Administrators: Core Technology: Lightweight translation scripts intercept commands pass python ‘engine’, based industry-standard packages run commands perform statistical disclosure checks System Requirements: - Python 3.10+ runtime environment - Standard scientific computing libraries (pandas, numpy, statsmodels) - Minimal computational overhead - external network dependencies analysis Security Features: - Local processing (cloud dependencies) - Audit logging tracking - Configurable disclosure thresholds - Role-based access controls (integration TRE systems) Documentation Support: Standard Python coding naming practices used throughout. GitHub continuous integration (CI) runners automatically generate publish API documentation using Python docstrings written numpydoc format

title: What ACRO-R Supports
text: Current Limitations: - Complex visualizations plots (coming future versions) - Time series analysis (specialized disclosure rules needed) - Machine learning models (use SACRO-ML AI/ML workflows) - Real-time data streams - Distributed computing frameworks Alternative Solutions: - SACRO-ML - machine learning AI model disclosure control - SACRO-Viewer - interactive output review approval - Traditional SDC tools - specialized use cases covered ACRO

what: ACRO: Tools for the Semi-Automatic Checking of Research Outputs
title: Welcome to ACRO-R
text: repository maintains ACRO R package, interface Python ACRO package. ACRO free open source tool supports semi-automated checking research outputs (SACRO) privacy disclosure within secure data environments. SACRO framework applies best-practice principles-based statistical disclosure control (SDC) techniques --fly researchers conduct analysis. SACRO designed assist human checkers rather seeking replace current automated rules-based approaches. ACRO package lightweight Python tool sits well-known analysis tools produce outputs tables, plots, statistical models. package adds functionality : automatically identify potentially disclosive outputs range commonly used disclosure tests; apply optional disclosure mitigation strategies requested; report reasons applying SDC; produce simple summary documents trusted research environment staff can use streamline workflow maintain auditable records. creates explicit change dynamics SDC something done researchers rather , enables efficient communication checkers. graphical user interface (SACRO-Viewer) supports human checkers displaying requested output results checks immediately accessible format, highlighting identified issues, potential mitigation options, tracking decisions made. Additional programming languages R package supported providing front-end packages interface core ACRO Python back-end.

title: Welcome to ACRO-R
text: using function package, acro object initialised using following R code:

title: Welcome to ACRO-R
text: github-pages contains pre-built documentation. Additionally, see paper describing SACRO framework learn principles-based SDC methodology usage.

title: Welcome to ACRO-R
text: work funded UK Research Innovation Grant Numbers MC_PC_21033 MC_PC_23006 part Phase 1 Data Analytics Research Environments UK (DARE UK) programme, delivered partnership Health Data Research UK (HDR UK) Administrative Data Research UK (ADR UK). specific projects Semi-Automatic checking Research Outputs (SACRO; MC_PC_23006) Guidelines Resources AI Model Access Trusted Research environments (GRAIMATTER; MC_PC_21033). project also supported MRC EPSRC [grant number MR/S010351/1].
